semantic_title: Initial vs Subsequent Encounter for Fractures - 7th Character Assignment and Treatment Phases
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes > c. Coding of Traumatic Fractures > 1) Initial vs. subsequent encounter for fractures

content.full_text: Traumatic fractures are coded using the appropriate 7th character for initial encounter (A, B, C) for each encounter where the patient is receiving active treatment for the fracture. The appropriate 7th character for initial encounter should also be assigned for a patient who delayed seeking treatment for the fracture or nonunion. Fractures are coded using the appropriate 7th character for subsequent care for encounters after the patient has completed active treatment of the fracture and is receiving routine care for the fracture during the healing or recovery phase. Care for complications of surgical treatment for fracture repairs during the healing or recovery phase should be coded with the appropriate complication codes. Care of complications of fractures, such as malunion and nonunion, should be reported with the appropriate 7th character for subsequent care with nonunion (K, M, N,) or subsequent care with malunion (P, Q, R). Malunion/nonunion: The appropriate 7th character for initial encounter should also be assigned for a patient who delayed seeking treatment for the fracture or nonunion. The open fracture designations in the assignment of the 7th character for fractures of the forearm, femur and lower leg, including ankle are based on the Gustilo open fracture classification. When the Gustilo classification type is not specified for an open fracture, the 7th character for open fracture type I or II should be assigned (B, E, H, M, Q). A code from category M80, not a traumatic fracture code, should be used for any patient with known osteoporosis who suffers a fracture, even if the patient had a minor fall or trauma, if that fall or trauma would not usually break a normal, healthy bone. See Section I.C.13. Osteoporosis. The aftercare Z codes should not be used for aftercare for traumatic fractures. For aftercare of a traumatic fracture, assign the acute fracture code with the appropriate 7th character. (Evidence: pg no: 80, L44-L62)
content.summary: Comprehensive guidelines for 7th character assignment in fracture coding, covering initial vs subsequent encounters, complications, Gustilo classification, osteoporotic fractures, and aftercare coding (Evidence: pg no: 80, L44-L62)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Determine if patient is receiving active treatment or routine care
Step 2: Assign initial encounter 7th character (A, B, C) for active treatment
Step 3: Assign subsequent encounter 7th character for routine care
Step 4: For complications, determine if surgical or fracture-related
Step 5: Use complication codes for surgical complications
Step 6: Use specific 7th characters (K, M, N, P, Q, R) for malunion/nonunion
Step 7: Apply Gustilo classification for open fractures when applicable
Step 8: Consider osteoporotic fracture codes (M80) when appropriate
